Fields.DialogueText: Oh, hello, Captain! Do watch your step...
Is this what I think it is?
That depends on what you think it is.
It looks like you're sawing holes in the forecastle.
Well, right now I am. I'll have them patched up again in a tick, though!

Fields.MenuText: I'm sure there were rules against ad-hoc maintenance.
Hopefully, before the Morganas come calling...
You're as good with metal as you are with fabric. I trust you.

Fields.DialogueText: None that I've heard of since the last time we discussed this. What Command doesn't know won't hurt them!
Better mine than one of the carriers'. Not that we've ever had to worry!
I'm glad to hear it, Captain! A good defense is nothing without the faith you have in it.
So what is the goal of your project?
Patching some of the hollow spots. Not all armour is on the outside.
Good thinking. How soon can you have this done?
Well, it's going to be a bit of a rush job. If today's Morganas keep their pace, I'll have the last one done right as we get within firing range!
Hers or ours?
Ours, of course! ... I think.
Let's rush it a little more.
@BATTLE
Sorry. No. Not happening.
Stop looking at me like that.
Please, Captain?

Fields.MenuText: For the last time, no. The crew doesn't need new uniforms!
... I'll humour you, but don't be surprised if I haven't changed my mind.
What is it this time, Southampton?

Fields.DialogueText: It's all about morale! What could the crew need more than that?
Smashing! I've been touching up this design, and I think...
Remember my idea for new uniforms for the crew? I've been looking at the lapels, and...
Enough. We're here to defend the Norwegian sea areas, not to play dress-up.
I'm not playing dress-up!
Then why do you keep stealing my crew to model?
I can't very well work without seeing my ideas in action, can I?
The crew can't work if they have to keep adapting to new designs!
Well, I'll just have to settle on one, won't I?
Southampton, that's not what I—
Let's leave it off for now, Captain. We're catching up to the Morganas.
@BATTLE
Look lively, Southampton. We're approaching Stavanger.
Right, then. What's our objective today?
We're here to protect the coast from Morganas.
A shame we can't protect the country from her enemies on land.
We're fighting a common enemy out here at sea. This is bigger than Norway.
All I know is that history has a way of repeating itself. When I think of those rats bringing back the Black Death again and again...

Fields.MenuText: Did you just compare Germans to rats?
You let me worry about the Germans. They're not our enemy today.
I'll keep a weather eye out.

Fields.DialogueText: You're right, Captain. Rats can't pilot U-boats.
Maybe not today. But this side of the North Sea, I'm always on guard.
You just give me the what, when, and where!
Looks as if we have company to our north. Did you give the signal?
I still don't see what's wrong with the alarm.
Nothing, Captain! The signal flags I made are just more... team-oriented?
If you say so.
@BATTLE
Sorted! I feel like I could take on five of her!
That's all well and good, but I've got some questions about those flags.
Of course!
That's an oddly familiar shade of blue on that Morgana alert flag. Where did you find it?
Oh... around. The crew helped. It's amazing what you can find just sitting around on a ship! ACHOO!
Indeed. Lots of big pieces stitched together, too. Almost as if taken from certain sailors' uniforms.
ACHOO! Bloody weather. You know, Captain, some of them were complaining that they couldn't find their field dress uniforms. I'd hate for them to go without.
Southampton, those flags have buttons.
You know, my starboard hull's aching a bit. Better go check up on—ACHOO! Cheers!
She's a great seamstress, but a terrible liar...
What am I going to do with you, Southampton?
You could always hear me out.
You're certainly giving me fewer options every day I don't. Go ahead.
Why do we have uniforms, Captain?

Fields.MenuText: Is that a trick question?
Visual shorthand. Uniforms tell everyone who you are and what you do.
Solidarity, I suppose.

Fields.DialogueText: It's what you'd call rhetorical, isn't it?
Yes, but there's more to the clothing than that!
Got it in one, Captain!
We've got the crew in a hodgepodge of uniforms from all over the world. Good for diversity, not so much for a unified fighting force.
Is it really that important?
A uniform's all about unity, isn't it? It reminds you that you're part of something bigger than yourself. That could be just what we need against the Morganas.
I wish I could help you, Southampton, but Command already has their work cut out for them with these international crews.
What with the language barriers and standardization of training, they're not going to fund projects that aren't critical to their efforts.
That's the beauty of it—I don't need any funding! You've seen my repair jobs. Everything I need I can find right here!
From the crew's closets, you mean.
All right, all right. I'll run it by you next time I want to use something. Actually, I've already drawn up some designs if you'd like to look at them.
I think today's Morganas have other ideas.
I suppose. After?
Fine. But no epaulettes.
@BATTLE
All right, let's see these designs.
You look this over, Captain. I'll put the kettle on.
Here's our tea, Captain... black for you, honey for me... What do we think?
I notice you've done away with the hats in most of these.
Can't stand the things! Unless they're pinned in place, they're just not worth the hassle. Nobody needs those things flying off in the heat of battle!
What are these spaces here on this one? Along the arms.
Room for the honour cords.
Command doesn't assign honour cords.
Not yet, they don't! Purple for injuries, like the Americans do; red for valour; black for meritorious emergency repair...

Fields.MenuText: Meritorious emergency repair?
You've certainly thought this through. This is all formal dress, of course.
Let's not get ahead of ourselves. I'll need to run this by Command eventually.

Fields.DialogueText: Can't do it all on my own, after all!
Put your best foot forward, I say. Besides, there should be less disruption if we begin with formal dress. Start at events and work up to everyday wear.
And when you do, you'll need case studies to point to!
I see that there's no moving you. Just communicate. Talk to the crew about what they want, talk to me about what can be done, and I'll see to this.
Thank you, Captain! And we'll both see to the Morganas out there. Dodgy seas today...
@BATTLE
You're making tea again? Hasn't it been a while since you slept last, Southampton?
I should be asking you that question. We Belles don't need to sleep, after all.
Well, I haven't been able. It's been too quiet.
That's the way I like things. Gives you time to think, get your handiwork in order...
Is it me, or do you get more domestic under pressure?
When the world's gone mad, you stick to what you know. And what I know is the calming power of chamomile and lavender tea.
Can't argue with that.
What do you know, Captain?
I know that we need to clean out the fjords and defend the North Sea islands.
Easier said than done, isn't it?
And an objective we can't complete unless everyone's working their hardest. I had to break up an argument in mess today. Some of the British and German crew members got a bit heated.
That's what I'm trying to fix. You'd think the new uniforms would help with... well, uniformity.

Fields.MenuText: It takes more than new clothes to overcome national rivalries.
I know you're trying, Southampton, but maybe you should focus on the task at hand.
Any other ideas?

Fields.DialogueText: Fashion is a strange beast, Captain. I've got to unite the crew without losing what makes them unique...
How can I do that when our crew are at each other's throats?
I've really been banking on this one lately. I'm trying to change things the best way I know how.
This tea is fantastic, by the way. You've really taken me on a tour of your best.
I'm glad you like it. It's one of my... Captain! That's it!
What?
I'll tell you after the Morganas are defeated! We didn't even have to wake up for these. Flags up!
I'm just glad you can sense these things...
@BATTLE
I cant believe I didn't think of it sooner. This came to me when you mentioned all the tea I've been introducing you to.
How much do you have, anyway?
Never enough, Captain, but that's beside the point. I've been biting at the uniform issue from the wrong end. How big is my complement again?
At least seven hundred sailors. There's no way you can make uniforms for all of them.
I don't think I need to, Captain. Once I show them a few of my prototypes, they'll petition you for new ones, and you'll forward our recommendations to Command.
Awful lot of assumptions riding on this. How are you even going to present this to the crew?
Bit of dinner theatre. I thought I'd throw a nice tea to start. Crew members of different nationalities, just getting away from it all, getting to know each other...
I'm not opposed to the idea, but I'm not yet understanding why you think it would help our crew better integrate.
Our crew has more in common than you realize, Captain. A common enemy, families and friends at home... once they figure that out, there's no way they won't get along!

Fields.MenuText: It's not what I would have come up with... but it might work. What do you need?
I'm not sure I can support this. If the crew just focuses on their work, there won't be another incident.
And if they don't?

Fields.DialogueText: Tea, obviously. I have the china and silverware, but we'll need a lot more to pull this off. Oh! Can't forget the scones, either...
That's precisely what's causing the incidents, Captain! Everyone has different approaches to their work. Different uniforms just keep that obvious. It's time they talked them out instead of clashing.
They will, Captain. As long as they're clothed differently, they'll treat each other differently. They need to see right away that we're all in this together.
I'll see what I can get from Norway. All I want is an assessment of the event and the crew's reception. I have to track our efforts somehow.
They'll be recorded. You leave the baking and designs to me!
One thing at a time. The Morganas are coming, and they smell blood.
Not to mention the tea. Peckish creatures, them.
@BATTLE
... And oh, by the way, wouldn't they like some brand new uniforms to serve in? Comfortable, too, if I've anything to say about it.
Do you have everything you need?
Enough. I'm not sure how severe rationing will be in the future, and I wouldn't want to impose on any civilians...
Don't worry about that. Whatever we think we need to win, we'll find.
I suppose you're right. If you're not busy...
Yes?
Could you help me with the scones?

Fields.MenuText: Honestly, Southampton, I've got a ship to run.
If it's quick. How many are we talking?
Only if I get to taste one.

Fields.DialogueText: Please, Captain? It's for the crew. These could do with their leader's touch.
Enough for at least... oh, I'd say a hundred. We can always make more if need be.
Only one. I'm holding you to it!
Then we'd better get started.
Fantastic! All right, we'll split this—you make the dough, and I'll start greasing the baking sheets.
Roger.
I still can't believe we found this many blueberries! We might have to make even more, just to stop them going bad. Except... bollocks! Belay that, Captain.
Morganas?
Well, yes, but I need to secure the ingredients! What if we're hit?
Priorities, Southampton.
@BATTLE
Bollocks.
Scone trouble?
The batter's fine, but the blueberries have been ruined!
Were they crushed while we were fighting the Morganas? We could still make cobbler.
Worse. The galley was hit, and something in the Morgana's shot must have rotted them instantly. Half the perishables are like that!

Fields.MenuText: What are you concerned about the scones for? We need to replenish our food supply!
Calm down. I'll see what we can get from the rest of the convoy.
We need to put ashore and restock. I'll take care of that, you take care of the galley.

Fields.DialogueText: I know, Captain! Just let me think... can we get enough supply in Finnmark?
I can't take what the other ships might need. Finnmark's our destination, isn't it? We can restock there.
Are you sure you don't need any help from me, Captain?
We'll get the food we need, there's no question about that. Iron rations until we make port.
The crew won't like that, Captain.
What choice do I have? We can't risk running out of what's left.
... If you're sure. Excuse me a moment, Captain.
Now where's she going?
Batch in the oven... And now we wait!
Not a moment too soon. I think we're about to have company.
Well, I'll just have to keep an eye on the clock then, won't I?
*ALARM*
@BATTLE
A moment of your time, Captain?
What's this? A letter?
Open it.
"The Town-class light cruiser HMS Southampton cordially invites you..." You've finished the invitations for your high tea!
The very highest. I thought the crew would appreciate it after the resupply... and the rationing that came before.
Will the uniforms be ready for the occasion?
They'd better be! I already sent the invitations to the rest of the crew and some others among our group.
How many are you expecting?
Two hundred. Maybe three. We're not the only ones who are tired.

Fields.MenuText: How do you expect to prepare for this?
We're still in contested waters. How can this possibly be safe?
What can I do to help?

Fields.DialogueText: Leave that to me.
Nowhere is safe, Captain. That's why this must be done.
Just keep me floating and fighting, Captain.
The Morganas are attacking our food. They know what makes humans tick. They need to see that they will not make us afraid.
You take your tea seriously.
And my ale, and my sausage. This isn't over, Captain—starting now, the crew's going to eat better, dress better, and live better than the Morganas could dream of taking from them.
Tell them that. There's a few starboard that need to hear it.
Don't need to tell me twice!
@BATTLE
Captain! I need to borrow your doilies!
I don't own any doilies.
What are you talking about? I covered your room with... Captain?
Southampton, why are you looking at me like that?
You didn't have to use them, Captain. But where did you put them? Choose your words carefully.

Fields.MenuText: Are you threatening your captain over your decorations?
I don't know! They can't very well have left the ship!
Check my locker. I don't remember them leaving my quarters.

Fields.DialogueText: Don't pull rank on me! This is a matter of life and death!
You say that, but I've been looking for three days! I've got table settings to lay out, haven't I?!?
Are you having a laugh? That was the first place I looked!
Calm down, Southampton. We're hosting the convoy's sailors, not royalty.
At sea, the Captain is second only to the King himself! That makes the crew your royal family. I will spare nothing for the entertainment of royalty!
Can you spare a few shells for the Morganas bearing down on us? After that's done I'll spend whatever time I have helping you look.
Blasted Morganas... reckon they wouldn't know quality lacework if I strangled them with it.
@BATTLE
How are the table settings coming?
They're coming. I'm running out, though. By my count, we've got tables for three hundred and tablecloths for two hundred and eighty.
I've done what I can, but I can only requisition so much linen for "team-building exercises."
Is that what we're calling it now? Bloody understatement, if I do say so myself. When I'm done with them, your crew will be inseparable!

Fields.MenuText: They'll certainly stand out in a crowd.
You think they'll feel that way?
I hope so. Your heart's in the right place.

Fields.DialogueText: Good. The world needs to know that our crew is top grade!
Call it an educated guess. They need some common ground that isn't the heat of battle.
In the stomachs of the crew, naturally. Best way to theirs!
But that still doesn't solve the issue of too few tablecloths.
Indeed. Well, not to worry. I'll just have to appropriate some more of their old uniforms.
You know I can't let you do that.
I don't like denim tablecloths any more than you do, but we have to work with what we've got.
That's not what I—
Not now, Captain! We've got Morganas at ten o'clock!
Perhaps we shouldn't have scheduled the rehearsal for this afternoon.
No need to worry—the tables have all been bolted to the deck!
Never mind.
@BATTLE
Captain, look lively! Tea starts soon!
We still have plenty of time left.
And I haven't given you your uniform yet.
My uniform?
They're not just for my models, you know! Change comes from below, but once the crew see you in what I've stitched up, I think you'll really move the needle!

Fields.MenuText: Are you sure you're not taking this far too seriously?
I hadn't noticed, actually.
You have a point. You look fantastic, by the way.

Fields.DialogueText: A ship can never take her crew too seriously, Captain.
Bit of advice, Captain? Stick to captaining. You're better at it.
Thank you, Captain. I work hard to do so!
In any event, what did you have in mind?
Much the same as your current uniform, really. But with improvements.
Oof... it's heavier than it looks.
Sewed some armour into it, just in case. You never know where you might be attacked.
On my own ship?
Who knows? I may be an impeccable decorator, but never forget that I am a warship and we are at war!
Funny you should mention that...
No! The Morganas! Why now, of all times?
I'll have the crew clear the furniture and get to action stations.
No, Captain! Those tea tables are bolted to the deck, and they shall stay that way! Let the Morganas see that they will not come between an Englishwoman and her tea!
But—
But nothing! Get that uniform on. We're facing these witches in our Sunday best.
@BATTLE
You might have noticed I've cleaned up a little myself.
I don't think I could eat another bite...
Told you.
I've got to hand it to you—I wasn't sure this would work, but you've proven me wrong. I haven't seen that much laughter since this war started.
Shame about the floral arrangements. They didn't survive the Morganas.
But thank goodness the scones did.
Oh, I'm so glad the sailors loved them! You know, I saw two Germans chatting up a storm with a table of Polish engineers. I don't know much of either language, but their faces said it all.
The way to a man's heart, and all that. Job well done.
And the uniforms! Our crew would be the pride of any fleet. Did you see those brilliant blue dress uniforms those Indian ensigns modeled?
I overheard a few tables discussing the uniforms.
Really? What did they say?
A few of your models had interesting things to say about your methods. Something about their clothes going missing?
Ridiculous, Captain! I only took the spare sets for the signal flags.
Only?
Mostly. I never appropriated anything I didn't intend to replace. Room for dessert, Captain?
Let's take care of our new friends first.
@BATTLE
Well, let's say it doesn't, Captain. At least it'll have been a breath of fresh air for the crew. It just falls to you and I to keep breathing.

Fields.MenuText: You really think this will catch on?
Your dress uniforms are certainly... elaborate.

Fields.DialogueText: There'll be workshopping and committees and long, boring meetings to pare it all down. If I shoot for the moon with these designs, I know they'll land among the stars!

Fields.MenuText: Any ideas for the service uniforms?

Fields.DialogueText: Quite a few, Captain, just aching to be shown off at the next tea!
*ALARM*
I came as quickly as I could, Captain! We're full speed ahead!
That's the spirit. We've just received word that Sola's under attack.
It's more than that! Stavanger's just on the other side of Hafrsfjord—the Morganas are shelling the entire fjord!
How do you—
Instinct, Captain. Belles are born with it.
I shouldn't be surprised. But now we've got them right where we want them.
What do you mean?
If we can trap the Morganas in the fjord, they'll have nowhere to run.
Captain, no. You saw what happened to Fair Isle. There's no guarantee that the citizens will be safe!

Fields.MenuText: You think it might be a trap?
Perhaps the Morganas know something we don't.
You're right, Southampton. But we've got to flush them out in any event.

Fields.DialogueText: The Morganas know the seas better than most humans do. They wouldn't trap themselves unless they were trapping us with them.
They know everything we don't, Captain! We can't let them choose where they fight... or where they sink.
And quickly! We can't let them contaminate the mainland.
We're doing this the hard way, then. We'll radio your sister cruisers and clear a path for our battleships.
Straight into the heart of it. I like it!
Don't be a hero, Southampton. Drawing their fire is our first priority.
Understood. But if one Morgana so much as glances at the shore, I'm aiming for her.
We'll do what we can.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
Confirmed sighting?
Off to port.
I thought for sure we'd scared them off.
Well, they're here. I suppose even Morganas get ambitious.
Not for long.
@BATTLE
What's the final toll?
Bad. But not catastrophic. Much of the industry and infrastructure had already been moved inland.
And the people? What about them?
A few hundred civilians, mostly fishermen and farmers. They're going to have to be resettled elsewhere.
What are we doing with them?

Fields.MenuText: That's for Norway to decide.
Aid to the wounded for as long as we're here in Stavanger.
There's little we can do. We've been assigned to another convoy from Britain.

Fields.DialogueText: Norway's three hundred miles away in Oslo. We're right here!
And after? We won the battle, Captain, but it's the least we can do to pick up the pieces.
That isn't enough. These people don't just need food. They need a home!
You're a light cruiser, not a passenger liner. Where do you expect to house everyone?
War isn't just destroying the enemy, Captain. We have to heal our allies. We have no greater allies than the people.
Have you been speaking to the Soviet Belles?
Never mind whom I've been speaking to! You moved heaven and earth to throw me a fashion show, Captain. Why so stingy now?
A fashion show? You pitched it as an integration proposal!
And didn't it prove to you that unity is our greatest weapon against the Morganas?
... This was your plan all along, wasn't it?
I don't know which Belles you've been talking to. Would I do anything behind your back?
Yes.
Then there's no point in stopping me, is there?
Apparently not. I'll set aside space for refugees' quarters.
You're bundled up today.
You know me. Can't stand the air on this sea. Chills me right to... right to...
Southampton?
ACHOO!
Tea?
If you'd be a love.
Let's get indoors.
Ugh... Captain, looks like tea will have to wait. Those Morganas have been following us since Hafrsfjord.
@BATTLE
Southampton, if you're not handling the cold, the refugees certainly aren't. How have they been?
Quiet. Keeping to themselves, but getting along as best they can. But they won't worry about the cold. I've made sure of that.
I've noticed their new sweaters. You've really taken to that Fair Isle technique.
I like the pattern. It's warm to wear, pleasing to the eye, calming to make.

Fields.MenuText: You haven't let it go, have you?
Do what you love and you never work a day in your life.
Where do they go from here?

Fields.DialogueText: I try and take the good from the bad. If it keeps them warm, all the better.
In some ways, I love a good war, if only to help rebuild.
I've had an idea for the resettlement. It'd keep them safe from Germans and Morganas alike.
Well, we certainly can't keep them with us forever.
We can't... but the Royal Navy certainly can. Captain, we're headed to the Orkneys as soon as possible!
... I see what you mean. We'll give it a go.
Here we are, Captain. Welcome to the Orkney Islands! Next stop - Scapa Flow, His Majesty's primary naval base!
Are we certain this will be safe?
Sheltered bays, far behind our patrols... what could be safer?

Fields.MenuText: We've no guarantee the Morganas won't attempt to come after us.
Sending the refugees inland, ideally.
If we break it, we fix it.

Fields.DialogueText: Let them try. The coasts are ours, and the people need to see it. They need to rebuild.
That would be like admitting defeat! We can't just fight them at sea, Captain. We need to fight them in our hearts and minds. We need to rebuild.
And what is broken can be rebuilt.
People aren't ships, Southampton. At some point we need to consider whether keeping to certain coasts is worth the risk.
Where else will these people go? They've made their livelihoods from the sea. We can't just uproot them.
Then why bring them to Scotland?
You'd rather leave them to the Germans?
Better humans than Morganas.
Not these humans, Captain. And not these Morganas. Let's give them a warm Orcadian welcome!
@BATTLE
How are the defenses, Southampton?
Honestly? They've seen better days. Practically no anti-air, the submarine blocks have all but collapsed... it's a bit of a fixer-upper, isn't it?
Against conventional navies. The Morganas are a different beast entirely.
Which is why we need to be ready for anything. I've had men shoring the base up sunup to sundown, with breaks only for tea.
Always got to keep one's priorities straight.
I understand the refugees are settling in?
There's a sizable Norwegian minority in Kirkwall. They're acting as intermediaries.
See, Captain? I told you, this couldn't be simpler!

Fields.MenuText: Maybe. I'm still uneasy about all this. For a naval base, this is pretty lackluster.

Fields.DialogueText: Exactly why it needs our attention! We've no shortage of materiel from the mainland and plenty of older vessels to sink for blockships.
We're seeing some Morgana activity near North Ronaldsay. Let's hope they don't get any bright ideas.
@BATTLE

Fields.MenuText: We're bringing them home eventually, right?

Fields.DialogueText: Once they have a home to be brought to. I've a feeling they're safer than they'd be anywhere on the Continent.

Fields.MenuText: Easy for us to say. We've got a home to go to.

Fields.DialogueText: And it should be open to anyone who needs one.
Yawn... fancy seeing you down here, Captain...
I don't think I've ever seen you look this tired, Southampton.
Heh... when I said I was only breaking for tea, I meant it!
I thought Belles didn't need to sleep?
Many don't at all. But that doesn't mean we don't enjoy a kip now and then.
What have you been doing lately? There isn't much you personally can do to fix up the base's defenses.
I do what I can when we're close. And I can have some equipment brought aboard if need be. Worst comes to worst, I can trim my hangar structure for spare steel.

Fields.MenuText: That's a little macabre.
You haven't actually done that, have you?
No, you can't. No matter what we do here, we need you in top shape.

Fields.DialogueText: Just thinking out loud. Humans and Belles are more alike than you think. You've just got different ideas of how to put your bodies to use.
I've bloody well thought about it. I know I'm supposed to draw fire, but the damn thing might as well be a signal flare. Entirely too bulky.
If the fleet's in top shape, then so am I. Can't keep them out of trouble otherwise.
You can't keep them out of trouble if you're exhausted.
I suppose you're right...
I know I'm right. Look, get some rest, and—
Captain! The Morganas—they're appraoching Scapa Flow! What are you standing around for? Where are the flags? Action stations!
That's one way to keep her awake... not that we should rely on it.
@BATTLE
Have you heard from Command yet?
Still haven't. Put that sailor down here. I'll have a medic attend to him as soon as possible.
What about London?
Radio isn't cooperating. Every frequency I try we get the same gibberish. What words we can make out are... detrimental to morale.
Let me guess: "Surrender," "Abandon all hope," "Your lives are forfeit..."
How did you guess?
We've faced the Morganas enough. I know what to expect from them.

Fields.MenuText: It doesn't bother you to hear these things?
Do you say anything to them?
Are they talking to you, or to us?

Fields.DialogueText: For some of us, it does. I listen, but it doesn't mean I believe what they say.
I would if I thought they might listen. Some of the Belles are more curious than others. I'll never understand Leningrad's fascination with them... or so I've heard.
That really depends on what they're saying, Captain.
So what about the things humans can't make out?
Oh, you really don't want to know. Tea?
Did you have that pot a moment ago?
All along. Maybe it's you that needs the sleep. Here they come again.
Sleep can wait.
@BATTLE
She's limping, Southampton! Increase speed and rake her with everything you've got!
Don't need to tell me twice, Captain.
Are you all right, Southampton?
Peachy. Why wouldn't I be?
Your tea's getting—
Hang the tea and give me a target.
@BATTLE
Looks like she's had enough. Are we getting radio again?
Affirmative, Captain.
Finally. I'll tell London we're no longer under siege. They'll—Southampton?
It's been attacked.
What has? What's happened?
Kirkwall. You didn't hear it, Captain, but I did. The Morganas told me.

Fields.MenuText: What do you mean, they told you?
Kirkwall's been hit? But we would have—
You don't mean...

Fields.DialogueText: Day and night. They told me everything they saw, everything they did. Everyone they killed.
No, Captain, you wouldn't have! Without your radio, you humans are deaf! Deaf!
Yes, Captain, I do mean. We might have saved the Royal Navy a base, but we weren't there to defend its people.
Calm down. We're just getting full information now that communications are back. What about the survivors? What about the refugees?
What about them, Captain? Do you want to hear about the ones that burned in their homes? The ones rotting at the bottom of the flow? The ones now crewing the Morganas?
This isn't over. We'll rebuild. We'll find some way to prevent this from happening again.
Excuse me, Captain. I think I've got some Morgana in my rudder.
I know why you're here, Captain. Whatever you're trying to say, it won't work.
I'm not trying to say anything. I just want you to come out of the engine rooms and talk to me.
I'm where I need to be, doing what I need to do.
And what might that be?
Maintaining the engines. Keeping my hull in order. Anything but making bloody uniforms or scones!

Fields.MenuText: Don't be so hard on yourself. You've done more than enough.
That doesn't have anything to do with Kirkwall.
Get back up to your quarters at once. You're scaring the men.

Fields.DialogueText: You told me that after Fair Isle. After that crewman jumped off my deck. How long until more than enough isn't enough?
That's what I'm saying! I ran myself ragged trying to fix Scapa Flow, I ran the crew ragged, and they were as well dressed and well fed as you please. What wasn't I doing?
There's worse things out there than a determined Belle. Not many things, granted, but they're there.
If you beat yourself up every time we lose people, you're going to have a hard time of it.
Who said war was supposed to be easy?
Nobody. We do what we can to make it easier.
Well, I haven't done enough.
For now, Westray Firth agrees. We're engaging Despair presently. If you want to make a difference, start with her.
Hmph. I'll make a hell of a difference in her superstructure.
That's the spirit.
@BATTLE
Sanday Sound today, Captain?
Correct. You're looking a little more composed today.
It comes and it goes. Shouldn't we be indoors?
We're just passing Muckle Green Holm. The last time Morganas were sighted, they were headed east past Stronsay.
This isn't right, Captain. If there's one thing we've learned from the Morganas, it's not to trust your eyes.
It's not just our eyes. The RAF's been conducting flyovers practically nonstop since Scapa Flow, and—
*BOOM*
Blast! Captain, are you all right?
I'll live! Flags up! Action stations!
@BATTLE
Ugh... are they gone?
Sunk, or driven back east into open waters. Easy now, Captain. You took a right nasty blow to the chest. You're lucky you're still upright.

Fields.MenuText: Thanks for having my back during that battle, Southampton.
Any idea what hit me?
Ah! Don't touch, it hurts like hell!

Fields.DialogueText: Of course, Captain. That Morgana had one hell of a firing range.
Bit of shrapnel from my hangar structure. Always hated that thing, I did. I've got to see about trimming it.
Well, that's what happens when you stand in a war zone, isn't it?
I feel like I've taken a torpedo to the sternum. How on earth did I survive that?
Well... remember that new uniform I made you? Not all armour's on the outside. An inch of it here and there... makes a difference, you know? Belles know that in a way humans really can't.
I... thank you.
I never told you where I got that armour, did I?
Does it matter? You saved my life.
It might. Trimmed it from an old war wound. You're wearing a bit of my starboard hull. Little piece of me. Fancy that.
You're a bloody wonder, Southampton.
It's the least I can do.
Been speaking to London?
And Command. We're not letting history repeat itself with Scapa Flow... or anywhere else.
Those eastern approaches past Burray are wide open. Not worth all the blockships it would take to fill them, is it?
No, but you've got the right idea. Parliament's mulling bridges between the islands to guard the Flow. Eliminates the need for ferries and forces enemy vessels to take the long way round.
Bloody brilliant! That's what we should have been working on all along.

Fields.MenuText: War's a learning experience. Whatever we lose, we can take measures to defend again.

Fields.DialogueText: A little like patching yourself up, isn't it?
You could say that.
I do say that. It doesn't get easier, but it's never a wasted effort. We can always take something good from what we do, no matter if it was exactly optimal in the moment.
A bit of trimming... What are your scissors made of, anyway?
You know, I've never really known. Something that cuts steel, at any rate.
Does it hurt?
Like bloody hell.

Fields.MenuText: We were acting on the best information we had.

Fields.DialogueText: We always do, Captain. But it could be better. It can be.

Fields.MenuText: Well, we'll get it right next time.

Fields.DialogueText: And if not then, we get it right the time after that. Just as long as there's a time to try.
Like your uniforms.
You laugh, Captain, but our crew's been thick as thieves since Sola.
Hard not to be, with ghost ships breathing down your neck.
It's not just fear that brings people together, Captain, or our crew wouldn't have needed the help. You need to look to your leaders and know you're part of something greater.
And if you are a leader?
You give your followers hope. A vision. A dream that one day things might be better... and that you'll be right there with them to help.
Which reminds me... I really ought to go fix that section of guardrail near my stern. A bit of trimming first...
*ALARM*
It'll have to survive for now.
Right.
@BATTLE
